issue.title: duration constructor from representation shouldn't be effectively non-throwing

blockquote.p: Members of duration shall not throw exceptions other than those thrown by the indicated operations on their representations.

discussion.p: Where representation is defined in the non-normative, brief description at [time.duration]/1:

blockquote.p: […] A duration has a representation which holds a count of ticks and a tick period. […]

discussion.p: [time.duration.cons]/2 doesn't indicate the operation undergone by its representation, merely stating a postcondition in [time.duration.cons]/3:

blockquote.p:
Effects: Constructs an object of type duration.
Postconditions: count() == static_cast<rep>(r).

discussion.p: I suggest this reformulation that follows the format of [time.duration.cons]/5.

blockquote.p: Effects: Constructs an object of type duration, constructing rep_ from r.

discussion.p: Now it is clear why the constructor would throw.

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N4750.

blockquote.pre: template<class Rep2> constexpr explicit duration(const Rep2& r);

blockquote.p:
-1- Remarks: This constructor shall not participate in overload resolution unless […]
-2- Effects: Constructs an object of type duration, constructing rep_ from r.
-3- Postconditions: count() == static_cast<rep>(r).

discussion.p: Priority set to 3. Improved wording as result of that discussion.

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N4750.

blockquote.pre: template<class Rep2> constexpr explicit duration(const Rep2& r);

blockquote.p:
-1- Remarks: This constructor shall not participate in overload resolution unless […]
-2- Effects: Constructs an object of type durationInitializes rep_ with r.
-3- Postconditions: count() == static_cast<rep>(r).
